awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: CEDAR: Large Amplitude Variations & Instabilities due to Strong Interactions between Tides & Planetary Waves in the Upper Mesosphere and Lower Thermosphere
awd_abstract_narration: This project is to characterize the role of nonlinear interactions, including instability, between tides and traveling and stationary planetary waves in generating variability in the upper mesosphere and lower thermosphere (MLT).  The work will focus particularly on the two day wave (TDW) in the summertime southern hemisphere, including studies on its amplification due to resonance with a subharmonic of the diurnal tide and consequent generation of a parametric subharmonic instability (PSI) as well as on the apparent association between phase-locked TDWs and pronounced enhancements of airglow emission brightness.  In addition, this project will investigate nonlinear forcing mechanisms which modulate tidal amplitude and/or produce non-migrating tides, particularly the westward semidiurnal tide which is dominant in the high-latitude upper mesosphere.  This effort will utilize a systems science methodology which combines ground-based wind and airglow intensity measurements, temperature measurements from the NASA TIMED satellite, the TIME-GCM  general circulation model, and a global data assimilation model.  This work will be conducted as a collaboration between international and U.S. educational, research, and small business institutions.
org_div_long_name: Division of Atmospheric and Geospace Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The objective of this work is to characterize and explain the amplification and diminishment of tides and planetary waves induced by nonlinear exchanges of energy between them. Of particular interest is the phase locked two day wave (PL/TDW) that is initiated and achieves its largest amplitude in the southern hemisphere during Austral summer. This wave is very nearly a subharmonic of the diurnal tide, which greatly diminishes as the PL/TDW amplifies. This suggests a Parametric Subharmonic Instability (PSI) mechanism. We focus on the PSI and its effects for large scale planetary waves (TDW) and small scale gravity waves. It has broad implications for geophysical flows and has important implications for interactions on smaller scales. We examine interactions between the two scales wherein the TDW may condition the atmosphere to support bore-like phenomena in the upper mesosphere. We examine in addition the source and seasonality of the semi-diurnal westward wave number 1 tide (SDW1) via an interaction between the migrating semidiurnal tide tides and a stationary planetary wave. We examine these phenomena in detail using ground based data from a collection of sites, satellite data, an assimilation model supported by ground based and satellite data, general circulation modes and a theoretical model of PSI interactions.

The accelerated two day wave was observed simultaneously at three southern hemisphere sites (Cerro Pachon, Chili and Adelaide and Darwin, Australia) during four austral summers. The analysis of meteor and MF radar data and airglow data shows that the strongest acceleration occurs when the TDW period is very close to 48 hours (phase locked to the diurnal period) and when the diurnal tide is strongly diminished. The theoretical considerations mentioned above support the idea that the phase locked two day wave is accelerated by a parametric subharmonic instability (PSI).

A detailed analysis of airglow and lidar data for Maui indicates the existence of instability structures when the atmosphere appears stable according to the conventional Richardson number criterion. Simulations with a theoretical model of wave-wave interactions supported a PSI explanation for high Richardson number instabilities and this may explain a significant fraction of the instability structures seen in the upper mesosphere. This finding indicates that the PSI mechanism operates over a broad range of scales in the upper atmosphere.

The large amplitude PL/TDW can have large effects on the ducting and growth of gravity waves propagating in the upper mesosphere. The conditioning of the upper atmosphere by the PL/TDW caused the formation of a dramatic bore event observed in the airglow over Adelaide, Australia.

We found that the semidiurnal westward propagating zonal wave number 1 (SDW1) tide shows up at Antarctic latitudes earlier and at lower altitudes than previously found. The early phase of the SDW1 may have a different source than the one occurring later.
